6.2. Let Us Start¶

Let us start section wise and complete each of the requirements

6.2.1. The Header¶

As we will be using an external stylesheet to style our web page, we first need to link that stylesheet to our Webpage using below :

<link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="css/page.css">

6.2.2. Image slider¶

Here we will be creating a responsive Image Slider, which displays the current discounts and offers going on.

The code snippet is as below :

        <div class="cycle-slideshow">
        <span class="cycle-prev">&#9001;</span>
        <span class="cycle-next">&#9002;</span>
        <span class="cycle-pager"></span>
                <img src="images/slide-1.jpg" alt="slide1" width="100%">
                <img src="images/slide-2.jpg" alt="slide2" width="100%">
                <img src="images/slide-3.jpg" alt="slide3" width="100%">
                <img src="images/slide-4.jpg" alt="slide4" width="100%">
                <img src="images/slide-5.jpg" alt="slide5" width="100%">
                <img src="images/slide-6.jpg" alt="slide6" width="100%">
                <img src="images/slide-7.jpg" alt="slide7" width="100%">
                <img src="images/slide-8.jpg" alt="slide8" width="100%">
        </div>
<!--End Responsive Image Slider -->


<!--Category Bar -->

Here we have used a pre-defined javascript jquery-2.2.0 and jquery-cycle2 which helps to make the slider. To use these javascripts we need to import two CSS files as below :

<script type="text/javascript" src="js/make.js"></script>
<link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="css/page.css">

After doing this, we will start with our Slider. For this we need to change few pre-defined classes in the above CSS.

  1. First class is cycle-slideshow which forms the basis of the basic <div> for the slider. We change few attributes to make it as per our requirement.
        .cycle-slideshow {
                width:100%;
                max-width: 1370px;
                display: block;
                position: relative;
                margin: 0px auto;
                overflow: hidden;
		background: green;
		
        }

max-width - Here used for responsive purpose. We can view the slider on smaller screens as well, without hampering the image.

overflow - It specifies, what to do if the content exceeds it container size. If overflow property is set to scroll then a scroll bar appears in case of overflow of content.

display - Specifies the type of box used for HTML element. Setting it to block displays it like <p>.

  1. The next class is the cycle-prev and cycle-next, which formats the arrow buttons used to navigate throught the slider for previous image and next image respectively.
        .cycle-prev, .cycle-next {
                font-size: 200%;
                color: #FFF;
                display: block;
                position:absolute;
                top: 50%;
                margin-top: -16px;
                z-index: 9999;
                cursor: pointer;

        }
        .cycle-prev { left:10%;}
        .cycle-next {right:10%; }

z-index - Here we have mentioned the z-index property, which specifies the layer of the element. It has been set to 9999 so that it is always on the top.

cursor - The cursor is set to pointer, which displays a hand when you

hover over the button.

&#9001 and &#9002 - These are the Unicode values for the buttons to be a shape of the arrow.

  1. Then, next class is the cycle-pager which actually holds the images for the slider.
        .cycle-pager {
                width: 100%;
                position: absolute;
                top: 20px;
                text-align: center;
                z-index: 9999;
        }

Images are inserted using the <img> tag discussed before.

6.2.3. Category Bar¶

Now we start with our category bar. The code snippet is as below:

<div id ="category" class="section-heading"> Categories </div>
<br><br>
<div id="cat_table" class="category_table"></div>
<br><br>
<!--Category Bar End-->

<!--Footer Start -->
<!-- Our CopyRight footer -->

Here we have used a class section-heading to style the headings of each section. The code is as below:

	.section-heading {
		text-align:center;
		font-size:40px;
		font-family: 'Della-Respira';
		text-decoration: underline;
	}

Next we have created another <div> with id=cat_table to create a table of all the categories stored in the database tables. The code for the class category_table is:

        .category_table {
                text-align: center;
                background-color: orange;
        }
        .category_table tr:nth-child(even) {
                background-color:brown;
        }

The nth-child(even) - Changes the background color of all the even Rows in the Table.

6.2.3.1. Javascript¶

As you can see there is no code written to retrive and display the categories on the page. This is because, the code for this section, is populated using Javascript.

We call a function make_table() when the web page is loaded, using javascript as discussed earlier.

The $(document).ready(function() is used to specify the functionalities which should be carried out at Page Load.

Now the make_table() function is written in javascript, which is a seperate file. So you all know, how to include that file in main_page.html :





Now we will see the Javascript Code :


function make_category_table () {
$.post( "get_category.php").done(function( data ) {
                result = jQuery.parseJSON(data);
                var cat_table = document.getElementById('cat_table');
                var i = 0;
                var j = 1;
                var numCols = 2;
                var row = ' ';
                var tbl = '<table border="1" align="center" width="100%"><tr>';
                for(var k in result) {
                        id = result[k].cat_id;
                        name = result[k].cat_name;
                        hide = result[k].hide_section;
                        src  = result[k].image;

                        row = row + "<td>" + "<a href=\"../08_product_page/product.html?search=" + name +"\"><img src=\""+src+"\"</img><br>" + name + "</a> </td>";
                        if (j%numCols == 0) {
                                tbl = tbl + row + "</tr>";
                                row = '';
                        }
                        j++;
                }
                cat_table.innerHTML = tbl + "</table>";
        });
       }





    

  1. Here as you can see, a PHP file is called, which actually fires the query to the database table and fetches all the categories. We will see the PHP code at a letr stage.
    2. 



#. The PHP code, return the data in JSON format so, it is stored using
jQuery.parseJSON(data) in result.


    

  1. Next we refer to the cat_table element og HTML, using document.getElementById function of javascript. The variable cat_table of javascript then refers to the HTML <div>.
    2. 

  2. There is a property of innerHTML which is used to set the content(inner HTML) of an element. We are using this property here to build the <div> for category table.
    3. 



#. We then define a variable tbl to store the HTML tags, and then we build
each row of the table using the data returned from PHP.


    

  1. You can see that, while building the row variable, we have passed a variable as search=name. It is done to pass the variable to the next page, so that we can use it there, by extracting it from the URL. Will discuss about it in detail when we create the product page.
    2. 



3. In the end we build the content using cat_table.innerHTML, and the table
is created on the main page.






6.2.3.2. PHP¶


Now we will see the PHP code, which actually fetches the data from MyZone
database tables. Below is the code snippet:


<?php

// create connection
try {
        if (gethostname() == "garima-lappy" || gethostname() == "rishi-lappy" ) {
                $pdo = new PDO('mysql:host=localhost;dbname=myzone', 'root', 'root123');
        } else {
                $pdo = new PDO('mysql:host=localhost;dbname=myzone', 'crestrou', 'Crestrou!23');
        }

//      $statement = $pdo->query("INSERT INTO categories (cat_id, cat_name) VALUES('$id', '$name')");

        $statement = $pdo->query("SELECT * FROM categories");
        $row = $statement->fetchALL(PDO::FETCH_ASSOC);
        echo json_encode($row);
} catch(PDOException $e) {
        echo $e->getMessage();
}
?>





    

  1. First we create a connection to the Database using PDO. Enter the host, database name, username and password.
    2. 

  2. Next we write the query to fetch all the categories from categories table.
    3. 

  3. FETCH_ASSOC return the result as an array, so it is easy to handle it. The result is returned to Javascrpt using json_encode.
    4.
